structs.name: ApiPositionsRequest

fields.name: sub_account_id
comment: The sub account ID to request for

fields.name: kind
comment: The kind filter to apply. If nil, this defaults to all kinds. Otherwise, only entries matching the filter will be returned

fields.name: base
comment: The base filter to apply. If nil, this defaults to all bases. Otherwise, only entries matching the filter will be returned

fields.name: quote
comment: The quote filter to apply. If nil, this defaults to all quotes. Otherwise, only entries matching the filter will be returned
Query the positions of a sub account

fields.name: event_time
comment: Time at which the event was emitted in unix nanoseconds

fields.name: sub_account_id
comment: The sub account ID that participated in the trade

fields.name: instrument
comment: The instrument being represented

fields.name: size
comment: The size of the position, expressed in base asset decimal units. Negative for short positions

fields.name: notional
comment: The notional value of the position, negative for short assets, expressed in quote asset decimal units

fields.name: entry_price
comment: The entry price of the position, expressed in `9` decimals
Whenever increasing the size of a position, the entry price is updated to the new average entry price
`new_entry_price = (old_entry_price * old_size + trade_price * trade_size) / (old_size + trade_size)`

fields.name: exit_price
comment: The exit price of the position, expressed in `9` decimals
Whenever decreasing the size of a position, the exit price is updated to the new average exit price
`new_exit_price = (old_exit_price * old_exit_trade_size + trade_price * trade_size) / (old_exit_trade_size + trade_size)`

fields.name: mark_price
comment: The mark price of the position, expressed in `9` decimals

fields.name: unrealized_pnl
comment: The unrealized PnL of the position, expressed in quote asset decimal units
`unrealized_pnl = (mark_price - entry_price) * size`

fields.name: realized_pnl
comment: The realized PnL of the position, expressed in quote asset decimal units
`realized_pnl = (exit_price - entry_price) * exit_trade_size`

fields.name: total_pnl
comment: The total PnL of the position, expressed in quote asset decimal units
`total_pnl = realized_pnl + unrealized_pnl`

fields.name: roi
comment: The ROI of the position, expressed as a percentage
`roi = (total_pnl / (entry_price * abs(size))) * 100^`

fields.name: quote_index_price
comment: The index price of the quote currency. (reported in `USD`)

fields.name: est_liquidation_price
comment: The estimated liquidation price

fields.name: leverage
comment: The current leverage value for this position

fields.name: cumulative_fee
comment: The cumulative fee paid on the position, expressed in quote asset decimal units

fields.name: cumulative_realized_funding_payment
comment: The cumulative realized funding payment of the position, expressed in quote asset decimal units. Positive if paid, negative if received

fields.name: result
comment: The positions matching the request filter

structs.name: ApiFillHistoryRequest

fields.name: sub_account_id
comment: The sub account ID to request for

fields.name: kind
comment: The kind filter to apply. If nil, this defaults to all kinds. Otherwise, only entries matching the filter will be returned

fields.name: base
comment: The base filter to apply. If nil, this defaults to all bases. Otherwise, only entries matching the filter will be returned

fields.name: quote
comment: The quote filter to apply. If nil, this defaults to all quotes. Otherwise, only entries matching the filter will be returned

fields.name: start_time
comment: The start time to apply in unix nanoseconds. If nil, this defaults to all start times. Otherwise, only entries matching the filter will be returned

fields.name: end_time
comment: The end time to apply in unix nanoseconds. If nil, this defaults to all end times. Otherwise, only entries matching the filter will be returned

fields.name: limit
comment: The limit to query for. Defaults to 500; Max 1000

fields.name: cursor
comment: The cursor to indicate when to start the query from
Query for all historical fills made by a single account. A single order can be matched multiple times, hence there is no real way to uniquely identify a trade.

Pagination works as follows:
  • We perform a reverse chronological lookup, starting from `end_time`. If `end_time` is not set, we start from the most recent data.
  • The lookup is limited to `limit` records. If more data is requested, the response will contain a `next` cursor for you to query the next page.
  • If a `cursor` is provided, it will be used to fetch results from that point onwards.
  • Pagination will continue until the `start_time` is reached. If `start_time` is not set, pagination will continue as far back as our data retention policy allows.

fields.name: event_time
comment: Time at which the event was emitted in unix nanoseconds

fields.name: sub_account_id
comment: The sub account ID that participated in the trade

fields.name: instrument
comment: The instrument being represented

fields.name: is_buyer
comment: The side that the subaccount took on the trade

fields.name: is_taker
comment: The role that the subaccount took on the trade

fields.name: size
comment: The number of assets being traded, expressed in base asset decimal units

fields.name: price
comment: The traded price, expressed in `9` decimals

fields.name: mark_price
comment: The mark price of the instrument at point of trade, expressed in `9` decimals

fields.name: index_price
comment: The index price of the instrument at point of trade, expressed in `9` decimals

fields.name: interest_rate
comment: The interest rate of the underlying at point of trade, expressed in centibeeps (1/100th of a basis point)

fields.name: forward_price
comment: [Options] The forward price of the option at point of trade, expressed in `9` decimals

fields.name: realized_pnl
comment: The realized PnL of the trade, expressed in quote asset decimal units (0 if increasing position size)

fields.name: fee
comment: The fees paid on the trade, expressed in quote asset decimal unit (negative if maker rebate applied)

fields.name: fee_rate
comment: The fee rate paid on the trade

fields.name: trade_id
comment: A trade identifier, globally unique, and monotonically increasing (not by `1`).
All trades sharing a single taker execution share the same first component (before `-`), and `event_time`.
`trade_id` is guaranteed to be consistent across MarketData `Trade` and Trading `Fill`.

fields.name: order_id
comment: An order identifier

fields.name: venue
comment: The venue where the trade occurred

fields.name: client_order_id
comment: A unique identifier for the active order within a subaccount, specified by the client
This is used to identify the order in the client's system
This field can be used for order amendment/cancellation, but has no bearing on the smart contract layer
This field will not be propagated to the smart contract, and should not be signed by the client
This value must be unique for all active orders in a subaccount, or amendment/cancellation will not work as expected
Gravity UI will generate a random clientOrderID for each order in the range [0, 2^63 - 1]
To prevent any conflicts, client machines should generate a random clientOrderID in the range [2^63, 2^64 - 1]
When GRVT Backend receives an order with an overlapping clientOrderID, we will reject the order with rejectReason set to overlappingClientOrderId

fields.name: signer
comment: The address (public key) of the wallet signing the payload

fields.name: broker
comment: Specifies the broker who brokered the order

fields.name: is_rpi
comment: If the trade is a RPI trade

fields.name: result
comment: The private trades matching the request asset

fields.name: next
comment: The cursor to indicate when to start the query from

structs.name: ApiFundingPaymentHistoryRequest

fields.name: sub_account_id
comment: The sub account ID to request for

fields.name: instrument
comment: The perpetual instrument to filter for

fields.name: start_time
comment: The start time to apply in unix nanoseconds. If nil, this defaults to all start times. Otherwise, only entries matching the filter will be returned

fields.name: end_time
comment: The end time to apply in unix nanoseconds. If nil, this defaults to all end times. Otherwise, only entries matching the filter will be returned

fields.name: limit
comment: The limit to query for. Defaults to 500; Max 1000

fields.name: cursor
comment: The cursor to indicate when to start the query from
Query for all historical funding payments made by a single account.

Pagination works as follows:
  • We perform a reverse chronological lookup, starting from `end_time`. If `end_time` is not set, we start from the most recent data.
  • The lookup is limited to `limit` records. If more data is requested, the response will contain a `next` cursor for you to query the next page.
  • If a `cursor` is provided, it will be used to fetch results from that point onwards.
  • Pagination will continue until the `start_time` is reached. If `start_time` is not set, pagination will continue as far back as our data retention policy allows.

fields.name: event_time
comment: Time at which the event was emitted in unix nanoseconds

fields.name: sub_account_id
comment: The sub account ID that made the funding payment

fields.name: instrument
comment: The perpetual instrument being funded

fields.name: currency
comment: The currency of the funding payment

fields.name: amount
comment: The amount of the funding payment. Positive if paid, negative if received

fields.name: tx_id
comment: The transaction ID of the funding payment.
Funding payments can be triggered by a trade, transfer, or liquidation.
The `tx_id` will match the corresponding `trade_id` or `tx_id`.

fields.name: result
comment: The funding payments matching the request asset

fields.name: next
comment: The cursor to indicate when to start the query from

fields.name: sub_account_id
comment: The subaccount ID to filter by

fields.name: currency
comment: The currency you hold a spot balance in

fields.name: balance
comment: This currency's balance in this trading account.

fields.name: index_price
comment: The index price of this currency. (reported in `USD`)

fields.name: event_time
comment: Time at which the event was emitted in unix nanoseconds

fields.name: sub_account_id
comment: The sub account ID this entry refers to

fields.name: margin_type
comment: The type of margin algorithm this subaccount uses

fields.name: settle_currency
comment: The settlement, margin, and reporting currency of this account.
This subaccount can only open positions quoted in this currency
In the future, when users select a Multi-Currency Margin Type, this will be USD
All other assets are converted to this currency for the purpose of calculating margin

fields.name: unrealized_pnl
comment: The total unrealized PnL of all positions owned by this subaccount, denominated in quote currency decimal units.
`unrealized_pnl = sum(position.unrealized_pnl * position.quote_index_price) / settle_index_price`

fields.name: total_equity
comment: The notional value of your account if all positions are closed, excluding trading fees (reported in `settle_currency`).
`total_equity = sum(spot_balance.balance * spot_balance.index_price) / settle_index_price + unrealized_pnl`

fields.name: initial_margin
comment: The `total_equity` required to open positions in the account (reported in `settle_currency`).
Computation is different depending on account's `margin_type`

fields.name: maintenance_margin
comment: The `total_equity` required to avoid liquidation of positions in the account (reported in `settle_currency`).
Computation is different depending on account's `margin_type`

fields.name: available_balance
comment: The notional value available to transfer out of the trading account into the funding account (reported in `settle_currency`).
`available_balance = total_equity - initial_margin - min(unrealized_pnl, 0)`

fields.name: spot_balances
comment: The list of spot assets owned by this sub account, and their balances

fields.name: positions
comment: The list of positions owned by this sub account

fields.name: settle_index_price
comment: The index price of the settle currency. (reported in `USD`)

fields.name: is_vault
comment: Whether this sub account is a vault

fields.name: vault_im_additions
comment: Total amount of IM (reported in `settle_currency`) deducted from the vault due to redemptions nearing the end of their redemption period

fields.name: derisk_margin
comment: The derisk margin of this sub account

fields.name: derisk_to_maintenance_margin_ratio
comment: The derisk margin to maintenance margin ratio of this sub account

structs.name: ApiSubAccountSummaryResponse

fields.name: result
comment: The sub account matching the request sub account
Query for sub-account details, including base currency balance, all derivative positions, margin levels, and P&L.

structs.name: ApiSubAccountHistoryRequest

fields.name: sub_account_id
comment: The sub account ID to request for

fields.name: start_time
comment: Start time of sub account history in unix nanoseconds

fields.name: end_time
comment: End time of sub account history in unix nanoseconds

fields.name: limit
comment: The limit to query for. Defaults to 500; Max 1000

fields.name: cursor
comment: The cursor to indicate when to start the next query from
The request to get the history of a sub account
SubAccount Summary values are snapshotted once every hour
No snapshots are taken if the sub account has no activity in the hourly window
History is preserved only for the last 30 days

Pagination works as follows:
  • We perform a reverse chronological lookup, starting from `end_time`. If `end_time` is not set, we start from the most recent data.
  • The lookup is limited to `limit` records. If more data is requested, the response will contain a `next` cursor for you to query the next page.
  • If a `cursor` is provided, it will be used to fetch results from that point onwards.
  • Pagination will continue until the `start_time` is reached. If `start_time` is not set, pagination will continue as far back as our data retention policy allows.

fields.name: result
comment: The sub account history matching the request sub account

fields.name: next
comment: The cursor to indicate when to start the next query from

structs.name: VaultInvestment

fields.name: vault_id
comment: The trading account ID of the vault invested in.

fields.name: num_lp_tokens
comment: The number of shares held by the investor.

fields.name: share_price
comment: The current share price (in USD) of this vault investment.
Summarizes a vault investment held by a funding account

fields.name: main_account_id
comment: The main account ID of the account to which the summary belongs

fields.name: total_equity
comment: Total equity of the main (+ sub) account, denominated in USD

fields.name: spot_balances
comment: The list of spot assets owned by this main (+ sub) account, and their balances

fields.name: vault_investments
comment: The list of vault investments held by this main account

fields.name: total_sub_account_balance
comment: Total balance of the sub accounts, denominated in USD

structs.name: ApiAggregatedAccountSummaryResponse

fields.name: result
comment: The aggregated account summary
The aggregated account summary, that reports the total equity and spot balances of a funding (main) account, and its constituent trading (sub) accounts

structs.name: FundingAccountSummary

fields.name: main_account_id
comment: The main account ID of the account to which the summary belongs

fields.name: total_equity
comment: Total equity of the main account, denominated in USD

fields.name: spot_balances
comment: The list of spot assets owned by this main account, and their balances

structs.name: WSSubscribeParams

fields.name: stream
comment: The channel to subscribe to (eg: ticker.s / ticker.d)

fields.name: selectors
comment: The list of feeds to subscribe to

fields.name: use_global_sequence_number
comment: Whether to use the global sequence number for the stream
All V1 Websocket Subscription Requests are housed in this wrapper. You may specify a stream and a list of feeds to subscribe to.
When subscribing to the same primary selector again, the previous secondary selector will be replaced. See `Overview` page for more details.
Sequence numbers can be either gateway-specific or global:
- **Gateway Unique Sequence Number**: Increments by one per stream, resets to 0 on gateway restart.

- **Global Unique Sequence Number**: A cluster-wide unique number assigned to each cluster payload, does not reset on gateway restarts, and can be used to track and identify message order across streams using `sequence_number` and `prev_sequence_number` in the feed response.
Set `useGlobalSequenceNumber = true` if you need a persistent, unique identifier across all streams or ordering across multiple feeds.

structs.name: WSSubscribeResult

fields.name: stream
comment: The channel to subscribe to (eg: ticker.s / ticker.d)

fields.name: subs
comment: The list of feeds subscribed to

fields.name: unsubs
comment: The list of feeds unsubscribed from

fields.name: num_snapshots
comment: The number of snapshot payloads to expect for each subscribed feed. Returned in same order as `subs`

fields.name: first_sequence_number
comment: The first sequence number to expect for each subscribed feed. Returned in same order as `subs`

fields.name: latest_sequence_number
comment: The sequence number of the most recent message in the stream. Next received sequence number must be larger than this one. Returned in same order as `subs`

To ensure you always know if you have missed any payloads, GRVT servers apply the following heuristics to sequence numbers:
  • All snapshot payloads will have a sequence number of `0`. All delta payloads will have a sequence number of `1+`. So its easy to distinguish between snapshots, and deltas
  • Num snapshots returned in Response (per stream): You can ensure that you received the right number of snapshots
  • First sequence number returned in Response (per stream): You can ensure that you received the first stream, without gaps from snapshots
  • Sequence numbers should always monotonically increase by `1`. If it decreases, or increases by more than `1`. Please reconnect
  • Duplicate sequence numbers are possible due to network retries. If you receive a duplicate, please ignore it, or idempotently re-update it.
When subscribing to the same primary selector again, the previous secondary selector will be replaced. See `Overview` page for more details.

structs.name: WSOrderbookLevelsFeedSelectorV1

fields.name: instrument
comment:
The readable instrument name:
  • Perpetual: `ETH_USDT_Perp`
  • Future: `BTC_USDT_Fut_20Oct23`
  • Call: `ETH_USDT_Call_20Oct23_2800`
  • Put: `ETH_USDT_Put_20Oct23_2800`

fields.name: rate
comment: The minimal rate at which we publish feeds (in milliseconds)
Snapshot (500, 1000)

fields.name: depth
comment: Depth of the order book to be retrieved
Delta(0 - `unlimited`)
Subscribes to aggregated orderbook updates for a single instrument. The `book.s` channel offers simpler integration. To experience higher publishing rates, please use the `book.d` channel.
Unlike the `book.d` channel which publishes an initial snapshot, then only streams deltas after, the `book.s` channel publishes full snapshots at each feed.

The Delta feed will work as follows:
  • On subscription, the server will send a full snapshot of all levels of the Orderbook.
  • After the snapshot, the server will only send levels that have changed in value.

Subscription Pattern:
  • Delta - `instrument@rate`
  • Snapshot - `instrument@rate-depth`

Field Semantics:
  • [DeltaOnly] If a level is not updated, level not published
  • If a level is updated, {size: '123'}
  • If a level is set to zero, {size: '0'}
  • Incoming levels will be published as soon as price moves
  • Outgoing levels will be published with `size = 0`

fields.name: price
comment: The price of the level, expressed in `9` decimals

fields.name: size
comment: The number of assets offered, expressed in base asset decimal units

fields.name: num_orders
comment: The number of open orders at this level

fields.name: event_time
comment: Time at which the event was emitted in unix nanoseconds

fields.name: instrument
comment:
The readable instrument name:
  • Perpetual: `ETH_USDT_Perp`
  • Future: `BTC_USDT_Fut_20Oct23`
  • Call: `ETH_USDT_Call_20Oct23_2800`
  • Put: `ETH_USDT_Put_20Oct23_2800`

fields.name: bids
comment: The list of best bids up till query depth

fields.name: asks
comment: The list of best asks up till query depth

fields.name: stream
comment: Stream name

fields.name: selector
comment: Primary selector

fields.name: sequence_number
comment: A sequence number used to determine message order within a stream.
- If `useGlobalSequenceNumber` is **false**, this returns the gateway sequence number, which increments by one locally within each stream and resets on gateway restarts.
- If `useGlobalSequenceNumber` is **true**, this returns the global sequence number, which uniquely identifies messages across the cluster.
- A single cluster payload can be multiplexed into multiple stream payloads.
- To distinguish each stream payload, a `dedupCounter` is included.
- The returned sequence number is computed as: `cluster_sequence_number * 10^5 + dedupCounter`.

comment: An orderbook levels object matching the request filter

comment: The previous sequence number that determines the message order

Unlike the `mini.d` channel which publishes an initial snapshot, then only streams deltas after, the `mini.s` channel publishes full snapshots at each feed.

The Delta feed will work as follows:
  • On subscription, the server will send a full snapshot of the mini ticker.
  • After the snapshot, the server will only send deltas of the mini ticker.
  • The server will send a delta if any of the fields in the mini ticker have changed.

Field Semantics:
  • [DeltaOnly] If a field is not updated, {}
  • If a field is updated, {field: '123'}
  • If a field is set to zero, {field: '0'}
  • If a field is set to null, {field: ''}

Derived data such as the below, will not be included by default:
- 24 hour volume (`buyVolume + sellVolume`)
- 24 hour taker buy/sell ratio (`buyVolume / sellVolume`)
- 24 hour average trade price (`volumeQ / volumeU`)
- 24 hour average trade volume (`volume / trades`)
- 24 hour percentage change (`24hStatChange / 24hStat`)
- 48 hour statistics (`2 * 24hStat - 24hStatChange`)
To query for an extended ticker payload, leverage the `greeks` and the `derived` flags.
Ticker extensions are currently under design to offer you more convenience.
These flags are only supported on the `Ticker Snapshot` WS endpoint, and on the `Ticker` API endpoint.

This endpoint offers public trading data, use the Trading APIs instead to query for your personalized trade tape.
Only data from the last three months will be retained.

Pagination works as follows:
  • We perform a reverse chronological lookup, starting from `end_time`. If `end_time` is not set, we start from the most recent data.
  • The lookup is limited to `limit` records. If more data is requested, the response will contain a `next` cursor for you to query the next page.
  • If a `cursor` is provided, it will be used to fetch results from that point onwards.
  • Pagination will continue until the `start_time` is reached. If `start_time` is not set, pagination will continue as far back as our data retention policy allows.

fields.name: client_order_id
comment: A unique identifier for the active order within a subaccount, specified by the client
This is used to identify the order in the client's system
This field can be used for order amendment/cancellation, but has no bearing on the smart contract layer
This field will not be propagated to the smart contract, and should not be signed by the client
This value must be unique for all active orders in a subaccount, or amendment/cancellation will not work as expected
Gravity UI will generate a random clientOrderID for each order in the range [0, 2^63 - 1]
To prevent any conflicts, client machines should generate a random clientOrderID in the range [2^63, 2^64 - 1]
When GRVT Backend receives an order with an overlapping clientOrderID, we will reject the order with rejectReason set to overlappingClientOrderId

structs.name: Order

fields.name: order_id
comment: [Filled by GRVT Backend] A unique 128-bit identifier for the order, deterministically generated within the GRVT backend

fields.name: sub_account_id
comment: The subaccount initiating the order

fields.name: is_market
comment: If the order is a market order
Market Orders do not have a limit price, and are always executed according to the maker order price.
Market Orders must always be taker orders

fields.name: time_in_force
comment: Four supported types of orders: GTT, IOC, AON, FOK:<ul>
• PARTIAL EXECUTION = GTT / IOC - allows partial size execution on each leg
• FULL EXECUTION = AON / FOK - only allows full size execution on all legs
• TAKER ONLY = IOC / FOK - only allows taker orders
• MAKER OR TAKER = GTT / AON - allows maker or taker orders
Exchange only supports (GTT, IOC, FOK)
RFQ Maker only supports (GTT, AON), RFQ Taker only supports (FOK)

fields.name: post_only
comment: If True, Order must be a maker order. It has to fill the orderbook instead of match it.
If False, Order can be either a maker or taker order. In this case, order creation is currently subject to a speedbump of 25ms to ensure orders are matched against updated orderbook quotes.
|               | Must Fill All | Can Fill Partial |
| Must Be Taker | FOK + False   | IOC + False      |
| Can Be Either | AON + False   | GTC + False      |
| Must Be Maker | AON + True    | GTC + True       |

fields.name: reduce_only
comment: If True, Order must reduce the position size, or be cancelled

fields.name: legs
comment: The legs present in this order
The legs must be sorted by Asset.Instrument/Underlying/Quote/Expiration/StrikePrice

fields.name: signature
comment: The signature approving this order

fields.name: metadata
comment: Order Metadata, ignored by the smart contract, and unsigned by the client

fields.name: state
comment: [Filled by GRVT Backend] The current state of the order, ignored by the smart contract, and unsigned by the client
Order is a typed payload used throughout the GRVT platform to express all orderbook, RFQ, and liquidation orders.
GRVT orders are capable of expressing both single-legged, and multi-legged orders by default.
This increases the learning curve slightly but reduces overall integration load, since the order payload is used across all GRVT trading venues.
Given GRVT's trustless settlement model, the Order payload also carries the signature, required to trade the order on our ZKSync Hyperchain.
All fields in the Order payload (except `id`, `metadata`, and `state`) are trustlessly enforced on our Hyperchain.
This minimizes the amount of trust users have to offer to GRVT

fields.name: sub_account_id

fields.name: client_order_id

fields.name: time_to_live_ms
comment: Specifies the time-to-live (in milliseconds) for this cancellation.
During this period, any order creation with a matching `client_order_id` will be cancelled and not be added to the GRVT matching engine.
This mechanism helps mitigate time-of-flight issues where cancellations might arrive before the corresponding orders.
Hence, cancellation by `order_id` ignores this field as the exchange can only assign `order_id`s to already-processed order creations.
The duration cannot be negative, is rounded down to the nearest 100ms (e.g., `'670'` -> `'600'`, `'30'` -> `'0'`) and capped at 5 seconds (i.e., `'5000'`).
Value of `'0'` or omission results in the default time-to-live value being applied.
If the caller requests multiple successive cancellations for a given order, such that the time-to-live windows overlap, only the first request will be considered.

structs.name: ApiCancelOnDisconnectRequest

fields.name: sub_account_id
comment: The subaccount ID cancelling the orders for

fields.name: countdown_time
comment: Countdown time in milliseconds (ex. 120000 for 120s).
0 to disable the timer.
Does not accept negative values.
Minimum acceptable value is 1,000.
Maximum acceptable value is 300,000
Auto-Cancel All Open Orders when the countdown time hits zero.
Market Maker inputs a countdown time parameter in milliseconds (e.g. 120000 for 120s) rounded down to the smallest second follows the following logic:
- Market Maker initially entered a value between 0 -> 1000, which is rounded to 0: will result in termination of their COD
- Market Maker initially entered a value between 1001 -> 300_000, which is rounded to the nearest second: will result in refresh of their COD
- Market Maker initially entered a value bigger than 300_000, which will result in error (upper bound)
Market Maker will send a heartbeat message by calling the endpoint at specific intervals (ex. every 30 seconds) to the server to refresh the count down.
If the server does not receive a heartbeat message within the countdown time, it will cancel all open orders for the specified Sub Account ID.

structs.name: WSOrderFeedSelectorV1

fields.name: sub_account_id
comment: The subaccount ID to filter by

fields.name: instrument
comment: The instrument filter to apply.
Subscribes to a feed of order updates pertaining to orders made by your account.
Each Order can be uniquely identified by its `order_id` or `client_order_id`.
To subscribe to all orders, specify an empty `instrument` (eg. `2345123`).
Otherwise, specify the `instrument` to only receive orders for that instrument (eg. `2345123-BTC_USDT_Perp`).

fields.name: stream
comment: Stream name

fields.name: selector
comment: Primary selector

fields.name: sequence_number
comment: A sequence number used to determine message order within a stream.
- If `useGlobalSequenceNumber` is **false**, this returns the gateway sequence number, which increments by one locally within each stream and resets on gateway restarts.
- If `useGlobalSequenceNumber` is **true**, this returns the global sequence number, which uniquely identifies messages across the cluster.
- A single cluster payload can be multiplexed into multiple stream payloads.
- To distinguish each stream payload, a `dedupCounter` is included.
- The returned sequence number is computed as: `cluster_sequence_number * 10^5 + dedupCounter`.

fields.name: feed
comment: The order object being created or updated

fields.name: prev_sequence_number
comment: The previous sequence number that determines the message order

fields.name: sequence_number
comment: A sequence number used to determine message order within a stream.
- If `useGlobalSequenceNumber` is **false**, this returns the gateway sequence number, which increments by one locally within each stream and resets on gateway restarts.
- If `useGlobalSequenceNumber` is **true**, this returns the global sequence number, which uniquely identifies messages across the cluster.
- A single cluster payload can be multiplexed into multiple stream payloads.

Subscribes to a feed of time-to-live expiry events for order cancellations requested by a given subaccount.
**This stream presently only provides expiry updates for cancel-order requests set with a valid TTL value**.
Successful order cancellations will reflect as updates published to the [order-state stream](https://api-docs.grvt.io/trading_streams/#order-state).

Each Order can be uniquely identified by its `client_order_id`.

fields.name: currency

fields.name: num_tokens
comment: The number of tokens to withdraw, quoted in tokenCurrency decimal units

fields.name: signature
comment: The signature of the withdrawal
Leverage this API to initialize a withdrawal from GRVT's Hyperchain onto Ethereum.
Do take note that the bridging process does take time. The GRVT UI will help you keep track of bridging progress, and notify you once its complete.
If not withdrawing the entirety of your balance, there is a minimum withdrawal amount. Currently that amount is ~25 USDT.
Withdrawal fees also apply to cover the cost of the Ethereum transaction.
Note that your funds will always remain in self-custory throughout the withdrawal process. At no stage does GRVT gain control over your funds.

fields.name: limit
comment: The limit to query for. Defaults to 500; Max 1000

fields.name: cursor
comment: The cursor to indicate when to start the next query from

fields.name: main_account_id
comment: Main account ID being queried. By default, applies the requestor's main account ID.
The request to get the historical deposits of an account
The history is returned in reverse chronological order

Pagination works as follows:
  • We perform a reverse chronological lookup, starting from `end_time`. If `end_time` is not set, we start from the most recent data.
  • The lookup is limited to `limit` records. If more data is requested, the response will contain a `next` cursor for you to query the next page.
  • If a `cursor` is provided, it will be used to fetch results from that point onwards.
  • Pagination will continue until the `start_time` is reached. If `start_time` is not set, pagination will continue as far back as our data retention policy allows.

structs.name: ApiVaultViewRedemptionQueueRequest

fields.name: vault_id
comment: The unique identifier of the vault to fetch the redemption queue for.
Request payload for a vault manager to view the redemption queue for their vault.
Fetches the redemption queue for a vault, ordered by descending priority.
Urgent redemption requests, defined as having been pending >90% of the manager-defined maximum redemption period, have top priority (following insertion order).
Non-urgent redemption requests are otherwise prioritized by insertion order, unless they are >5x the size of the smallest redemption request.
E.g., If FIFO ordering (all non-urgent) is 1k -> 50k -> 100k -> 20k -> 10k -> 25k, then priority ordering is 1k -> 10k -> 50k -> 20k -> 100k -> 25k.
Only displays redemption requests that are eligible for automated redemption, i.e., have been pending for the manager-defined minimum redemption period.

The list of asset kinds that are supported on the GRVT exchange

values.name: SIMPLE_CROSS_MARGIN
comment: Simple Cross Margin Mode: all assets have a predictable margin impact, the whole subaccount shares a single margin

values.name: PORTFOLIO_CROSS_MARGIN
comment: Portfolio Cross Margin Mode: asset margin impact is analysed on portfolio level, the whole subaccount shares a single margin

values.name: UNSPECIFIED
comment: order is not cancelled or rejected

values.name: CLIENT_CANCEL
comment: client called a Cancel API

values.name: CLIENT_BULK_CANCEL
comment: client called a Bulk Cancel API

values.name: CLIENT_SESSION_END
comment: client called a Session Cancel API, or set the WebSocket connection to 'cancelOrdersOnTerminate'

values.name: MARKET_CANCEL
comment: the market order was cancelled after no/partial fill. Lower precedence than other TimeInForce cancel reasons

values.name: IOC_CANCEL
comment: the IOC order was cancelled after no/partial fill

values.name: AON_CANCEL
comment: the AON order was cancelled as it could not be fully matched

values.name: FOK_CANCEL
comment: the FOK order was cancelled as it could not be fully matched

values.name: EXPIRED
comment: the order was cancelled as it has expired

values.name: FAIL_POST_ONLY
comment: the post-only order could not be posted into the orderbook

values.name: FAIL_REDUCE_ONLY
comment: the reduce-only order would have caused position size to increase

values.name: MM_PROTECTION
comment: the order was cancelled due to market maker protection trigger

values.name: SELF_TRADE_PROTECTION
comment: the order was cancelled due to self-trade protection trigger

values.name: SELF_MATCHED_SUBACCOUNT
comment: the order matched with another order from the same sub account

values.name: OVERLAPPING_CLIENT_ORDER_ID
comment: an active order on your sub account shares the same clientOrderId

values.name: BELOW_MARGIN
comment: the order will bring the sub account below initial margin requirement

values.name: LIQUIDATION
comment: the sub account is liquidated (and all open orders are cancelled by Gravity)

values.name: INSTRUMENT_INVALID
comment: instrument is invalid or not found on Gravity

values.name: INSTRUMENT_DEACTIVATED
comment: instrument is no longer tradable on Gravity. (typically due to a market halt, or instrument expiry)

values.name: SYSTEM_FAILOVER
comment: system failover resulting in loss of order state

values.name: UNAUTHORISED
comment: the credentials used (userSession/apiKeySession/walletSignature) is not authorised to perform the action

values.name: SESSION_KEY_EXPIRED
comment: the session key used to sign the order expired

values.name: SUB_ACCOUNT_NOT_FOUND
comment: the subaccount does not exist

values.name: NO_TRADE_PERMISSION
comment: the signature used to sign the order has no trade permission

values.name: UNSUPPORTED_TIME_IN_FORCE
comment: the order payload does not contain a supported TimeInForce value

values.name: MULTI_LEGGED_ORDER
comment: the order has multiple legs, but multiple legs are not supported by this venue

values.name: EXCEED_MAX_POSITION_SIZE
comment: the order would have caused the subaccount to exceed the max position size

values.name: EXCEED_MAX_SIGNATURE_EXPIRATION
comment: the signature supplied is more than 30 days in the future

values.name: MARKET_ORDER_WITH_LIMIT_PRICE
comment: the market order has a limit price set

values.name: CLIENT_CANCEL_ON_DISCONNECT_TRIGGERED
comment: client cancel on disconnect triggered

values.name: OCO_COUNTER_PART_TRIGGERED
comment: the OCO counter part order was triggered

values.name: REDUCE_ONLY_LIMIT
comment: the remaining order size was cancelled because it exceeded current position size

values.name: CLIENT_REPLACE
comment: the order was replaced by a client replace request

values.name: DERISK_MUST_BE_IOC
comment: the derisk order must be an IOC order

values.name: DERISK_MUST_BE_REDUCE_ONLY
comment: the derisk order must be a reduce-only order

values.name: DERISK_NOT_SUPPORTED
comment: derisk is not supported

values.name: INVALID_ORDER_TYPE
comment: the order type is invalid

values.name: CURRENCY_NOT_DEFINED
comment: the currency is not defined

values.name: INVALID_CHAIN_ID
comment: the chain ID is invalid

values.name: PENDING
comment: Order has been sent to the matching engine and is pending a transition to open/filled/rejected.

values.name: OPEN
comment: Order is actively matching on the matching engine, could be unfilled or partially filled.

values.name: FILLED
comment: Order is fully filled and hence closed. Taker Orders can transition directly from pending to filled, without going through open.

values.name: REJECTED
comment: Order is rejected by matching engine since if fails a particular check (See OrderRejectReason). Once an order is open, it cannot be rejected.

values.name: CANCELLED
comment: Order is cancelled by the user using one of the supported APIs (See OrderRejectReason). Before an order is open, it cannot be cancelled.

enums.name: TimeInForce

values.name: GOOD_TILL_TIME
comment: GTT - Remains open until it is cancelled, or expired

values.name: ALL_OR_NONE
comment: AON - Either fill the whole order or none of it (Block Trades Only)

values.name: IMMEDIATE_OR_CANCEL
comment: IOC - Fill the order as much as possible, when hitting the orderbook. Then cancel it

values.name: FILL_OR_KILL
comment: FOK - Both AoN and IoC. Either fill the full order when hitting the orderbook, or cancel it

values.name: RETAIL_PRICE_IMPROVEMENT
comment: RPI - A GTT + PostOnly maker order, that can only be taken by non-algorithmic UI users.
|                       | Must Fill All | Can Fill Partial |
| Must Fill Immediately | FOK           | IOC              |
| Can Fill Till Time    | AON           | GTC              |

enums.name: TriggerBy

values.name: UNSPECIFIED
comment: no trigger condition

values.name: INDEX
comment: INDEX - Order is activated when the index price reaches the trigger price

values.name: LAST
comment: LAST - Order is activated when the last trade price reaches the trigger price

values.name: MID
comment: MID - Order is activated when the mid price reaches the trigger price

values.name: MARK
comment: MARK - Order is activated when the mark price reaches the trigger price
Defines the price type that activates a Take Profit (TP) or Stop Loss (SL) order.
Trigger orders are executed when the selected price type reaches the specified trigger price.Different price types ensure flexibility in executing strategies based on market conditions.

enums.name: TriggerType

values.name: UNSPECIFIED
comment: Not a trigger order. The order executes normally without any trigger conditions.

values.name: TAKE_PROFIT
comment: Take Profit Order - Executes when the price reaches a specified level to secure profits.

values.name: STOP_LOSS
comment: Stop Loss Order - Executes when the price reaches a specified level to limit losses.
Defines the type of trigger order used in trading, such as Take Profit or Stop Loss.
Trigger orders allow execution based on pre-defined price conditions rather than immediate market conditions.

enums.name: VaultRedemptionReqAgeCategory

values.name: NORMAL
comment: This request is at least as old as the minimum redemption period, and is eligible for automated redemption.

values.name: URGENT
comment: This request is nearing the maxmimum redemption period and will be factored into pre-order check margin requirements.

values.name: OVERDUE
comment: This request has exceeded the maximum redemption period and will be considered for forced redemptions.

values.name: PRE_MIN
comment: This request has yet to exceed the minimum redemption period, and is not yet eligible for automated redemption.
Denotes the age category of a given redemption request.

enums.name: Venue

values.name: ORDERBOOK
comment: the trade is cleared on the orderbook venue

values.name: RFQ
comment: the trade is cleared on the RFQ venue
The list of Trading Venues that are supported on the GRVT exchange
